qas.question: During which decade was assention by commission discontinued?
When does assention by commission occur today?

answers.text: once a year, at the end of the annual parliamentary session

qas.question: In whatear did several members refuse to attend the assention ceremony after a heated debate?
What was passed in reference to the discord in 1960 and 1965 during assention cremonies?
The ceremony of assenting by commission was continued in what decade?
The German Usher of the Black Rod summoned whom in 1960?

plausible_answers.text: creating an additional form for the granting of royal assent

qas.question: The Royal Assent Act 1968 was passed why?
The granting of what by the monarch in person is no longer possible?

context: During <a0_0>the <b4_0>1960s<b4_0/><a0_0/>, the ceremony of assenting by commission was discontinued and is now only employed <a1_0>once a year, at the end of the annual parliamentary session<a1_0/>. In <a2_0>1960<a2_0/>, the Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod arrived to summon the <b5_0>House of Commons<b5_0/> during a heated debate and several members protested against the disruption by refusing to attend the ceremony. The debacle was repeated in 1965; this time, when the Speaker left the chair to go to the House of Lords, some members continued to make speeches. As a result, the <a3_0>Royal Assent Act 1967<a3_0/> was passed, <b6_0>creating an additional form for the granting of royal assent<b6_0/>. As the attorney-general explained, "there has been a good deal of resentment not only at the loss of Parliamentary time that has been involved but at the breaking of the thread of a possibly eloquent speech and the disruption of a debate that may be caused." The granting of <b7_0>assent<b7_0/> by the monarch in person, or by commission, is still possible, but this third form is used on a day-to-day basis.
